so Azure static web apps what is azure static web apps well it's a fairly new
service from Azure to help you get out and deploy your static web apps it has a
code First Development approach and really nice hosting options that allow
you to build and deploy your code directly from the repository there's a lot of great features that we'll cover
today that helps you get up and running but it's a serverless solution so that means it's all managed by Azure and you
don't have to worry about a lot of that configuration and infrastructure management that happens behind the scenes
so some of the features and the way that it works is that it integrates your code changes directly into your repository so
it has first class integration to a few different code providers including GitHub and Azure devops and so you do
your code changes to your Source control and from there it directly does the report deployments and integration into
Azure and then from there it hosts your static content so whether that be your HTML and JavaScript or using something
like laser webassembly in the front end and then your serverless API functions in the back ends it makes it so that
it's really easy has that full integration pipeline for you so some other features are that it comes
with globally distributed static hosting so it means that all of your content is a globally available for your users
whatever they may be in the world there's that streamline building deployment that is sort of the main
focus for this and there's also custom domains and free tele TLS and SSL
certificates available for you so you get that really professional website from the start it has built-in authentication providers
and routing rules for you so you can secure your application with doing minimal code changes and options to
provide custom authentication and get more advanced with that as well as well
as generated staging environments so when you put up a pull request it'll automatically create a staging environment for you so that your
teammate can see live what your changes look like know more of this it works on
my machine vehicle can go out and test it for themselves there's also some really great tools that we'll take a

web apps what we need to use is something called Blazer webassembly so Blazer is a new full-featured front-end
framework from the world of.net so it allows you to run.net on the client side
using webassembly so your.net is actually running in the browser when using Blazer webassembly there is
another option for Blazer that's called Blazer server that runs it on the server side but because of a static web apps
you need that static content in the front end you need it running on the client side so we're going to be focusing on laser webassembly
specifically for this talk but with either option of laser that you're using you can have a shared component model
across the client and server you can share things with your front and back end and have those shared data libraries
across everything which makes it really nice to build those full stack.net web applications you can also use the same
toolkit the same visual studio the same whatever tools you use for your.net development to write your front-end apps
as well which makes it really nice it's part of the ASP netcore family so

you're building a regular full application you can have it hosted within your asp.net application
or you can have a standalone version which allows you to pair your globally distributed hosting of your content in
the front end with some powerful micro services in the back and so that Standalone option is what is
leveraged within the Azure static web apps so we're preparing our blazer webassembly with some serverless

generally available option for our apis is to use Azure functions within the

there's other types of triggers that you can use and they have that automated event as driven scaling that's built in
they're serverless so we don't have to worry about the infrastructure management Azure takes care of that for
us and has the flexible pricing options to go along with it and new in.net 7 there's something called the isolated
worker model which really improves the flexibility of the Azure functions how we can work with them as well
so the isolated work model what it does is it isolates the function's runtime process from everything else so it means
that we have more full control over the process it's easier to do that middleware support and the dependency
injection is a bit more natural to us and it matches up with how we do our dependency injection in the rest of
